TEXT.English: Teutonic Major Chapter Houses allow for the construction of Teutonic Knights.
TEXT.French: Teutonic Major Chapter Houses allow for the construction of Teutonic Knights.
TEXT.German: Teutonic Major Chapter Houses allow for the construction of Teutonic Knights.
TEXT.Italian: Teutonic Major Chapter Houses allow for the construction of Teutonic Knights.
TEXT.Spanish: Teutonic Major Chapter Houses allow for the construction of Teutonic Knights.

TEXT.English: Besides serving as a barracks and castle, Montfort allows for the construction of Marshall of the Teutons.
TEXT.French: Besides serving as a barracks and castle, Montfort allows for the construction of Marshall of the Teutons..
TEXT.German: Besides serving as a barracks and castle, Montfort allows for the construction of Marshall of the Teutons.
TEXT.Italian: Besides serving as a barracks and castle, Montfort allows for the construction of Marshall of the Teutons.
TEXT.Spanish: Besides serving as a barracks and castle, Montfort allows for the construction of Marshall of the Teutons.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In 1143 Pope Celestine II ordered the Knights Hospitaller to take over management of a German Hospital in Jerusalem, which, according to the chronicler Jean d’Ypres, accommodated the countless German pilgrims and crusaders who could neither speak the local tongue (i.e. French) nor Latin (patrie linguam ignorantibus atque Latinam).[1] However, although formally an institution of the Hospitallers, the pope commanded that the prior and the brothers of the domus Teutonicorum (house of the Germans) should always be Germans themselves, so a tradition of a German-led religious institution could develop during the 12th century in Palestine.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The name of the fortress derives from the two French words mont (a mountain) and fort (strong), meaning the "strong mountain". When the fortress was sold from the French De Milly family to the German Teutonic Knights, the fortress was accordingly called Starkenberg, meaning the same phrase in German (stark meaning strong, and berg meaning mountain).
TEXT.French: [TAB]The name of the fortress derives from the two French words mont (a mountain) and fort (strong), meaning the "strong mountain". When the fortress was sold from the French De Milly family to the German Teutonic Knights, the fortress was accordingly called Starkenberg, meaning the same phrase in German (stark meaning strong, and berg meaning mountain).
